## Try It Yourself

::: {.callout-tip}
## How to Practice
1. **Run the code** to see how reverse scoring works
2. **Verify** the reversal by checking original + reversed = 6
3. **Copy to RStudio** and try with your own data
:::

### Load the Data First

```{webr-r}
library(readr)
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE)

cat("Data loaded! Items G1, G3, G5, and G6 need reversing.")
```

### Look at Original Values

```{webr-r}
library(readr)
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE)

# See the original G1 values
head(data$G1, 10)
```

### Apply the Reverse Formula

For a 1-5 scale: `reversed = 6 - original`

```{webr-r}
library(readr)
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE)

# Reverse score G1
data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1

# Compare original and reversed
head(data[, c("G1", "rev_G1")])
```

::: {.callout-note}
## Challenge
What would the formula be for a 1-7 scale? Try it!
:::

### Verify the Reversal

Original + reversed should always equal 6:

```{webr-r}
library(readr)
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE)

data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1

# Check: should all be 6
head(data$G1 + data$rev_G1)
```

### Reverse Multiple Items

Now reverse G3, G5, and G6 as well:

```{webr-r}
library(readr)
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE)

# Reverse all four items that need it
data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1
data$rev_G3 <- 6 - data$G3
data$rev_G5 <- 6 - data$G5
data$rev_G6 <- 6 - data$G6

# Check G3
head(data[, c("G3", "rev_G3")])
```

### Create Subscale Scores

Calculate the two Grit subscales using the **reversed** versions:

```{webr-r}
library(readr)
data_url <- "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/LittleMonkeyLab/datarepo/main/Y1_Week13_Lab1_grit_data.csv"
data <- read_csv(data_url, show_col_types = FALSE)

data$rev_G1 <- 6 - data$G1
data$rev_G3 <- 6 - data$G3
data$rev_G5 <- 6 - data$G5
data$rev_G6 <- 6 - data$G6

# Consistency of Interest (G1, G3, G5, G6 - all reversed)
data$consistency <- data$rev_G1 + data$rev_G3 + data$rev_G5 + data$rev_G6

# Perseverance of Effort (G2, G4, G7, G8 - no reversing needed)
data$perseverance <- data$G2 + data$G4 + data$G7 + data$G8

# View result
head(data[, c("ID", "Study_Year", "consistency", "perseverance")])
```

## Self-Assessment

Check your understanding before moving on.

::: {.webex-check .webex-box}

**1. Why do we reverse-score some questionnaire items?**

`r mcq(c("To make the data look better", answer = "Because some items are negatively worded", "To reduce the sample size", "To increase variability"))`

**2. For a 1-5 scale, the reverse scoring formula is: `r fitb("6")` - original**

**3. If the original score is 2 on a 1-5 scale, the reversed score is `r fitb("4")`**

**4. True or False: When creating a total score, you should use the original (unreversed) items.**

`r torf(FALSE)`

**5. To verify reverse scoring worked, original + reversed should equal:**

`r mcq(c("0", "5", answer = "6 (for 1-5 scale)", "10"))`

:::
